column4: Have you tried rebooting with the headset not plugged in, and then plugging it in afterwards? I know that sounds stupid but trust me on this, sometimes it helps.
yes :)
Okay, my next guess is going to be googling pulseaudio and USB headset.
but I'm not seeing anything

I've spent countless hours in the past week and a half Googling around for the solution, that's why I eventually posted on the Ubuntu forum and I've also asked in #pulseaudio but no one seems to be able to help.
I've found a post that may help
I'd love to see :)
It basically says switch every preference to alsa and uninstall pulseaudio. =/
http://linuxowns.wordpress.com/2008/07/08/how-i-got-my-usb-headset-to-work/
yea, I've seen that as well.
when asking around about switching from pulseaudio back to alsa I was told it was a bad idea.
There may be some truth to that. I haven't had any problems with pulseaudio, but I also do not use a usb headset.
bluetooth works fine though
what bothers me is it was working originally.
OH MAN LIFECHAT that's even the same headset I have at home for the windows machine.
aye, it works fine on other operating systems
Historically, windows has had better sound than linux...for....decades. Which is unfortunate, but it's because they set all the standards on anything windows related that uses sound.
I wonder if there is a way to make a USB headset use ALSA
instead of Pulse?
I know, it is quite unfortunate, I had never had issues with sound in Ubuntu, but recently it's been awful.
